Contributions intended for the Soldiers" Ledge, or for the sick and wounded soldiers, can be left with the members of the Army Committee, as follows: W. P. Manford, at office of J. M. & K. Company; J. and Jas. near

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 54, page 3.

div3.head: River defences again.
div3.p: It is stated that iron gunboats are being prepared at Annapolis for the purpose of passing our batteries on James river.

We have often remarked that land batteries, properly constructed, can never be silenced by vessels of any size, and that in the general history of all warfare, with the exception of the present war, in which our batteries, with few exceptions, have been of the most miserable description, land fortifications have always proved too much for ships.
But batteries can be passed without much danger by gunboats at full speed, and, to meet this contingency, vessels loaded with stone should be sunk in the channel, and, if necessary, iron clad piles be also driven in, surrounded by chevaux de frieze of treer, which could be easily cut down from the neighboring shore, and so arranged as to give the enemy a tangled knot to untie before he could get at the obstructions in the river.
In addition to this, bomb proof batteries commanding the channel should be placed on the shore, and other batteries farther back, commanding any spot at which the enemy might attempt to land.
This, we are assured by high naval authority, is the proper and the only reliable mode of defending a river.
The experience of Fort Donelson has happily demonstrated a fact before unknown, that ever iron clad steamers are no match for rifled thirty-two pounders, and still less for one hundred and twenty pounders.
This is the confession of the Yankees themselves, and we are, therefore, warranted in believing that, with proper defences, armed with guns of this description, no steamers that the enemy can build can come up James river.
The Confederate authorities and the City Council should consult on the subject our leading naval men, and what they d do quickly.

div3.head: Batteries and iron-clad steamers
div3.p:
The battle at Fort Donelson seems to have shown that even iron plated steamers are no match for land fortifications armed with guns of a certain description.
The Yankee was terribly handled by the Confederate batteries.
A Yankee correspondent, who witnessed the engagement, says:

cit.q: "The fact is, our boats are proof against ordinary shot, even as large as a sixty-four, but this trial has demonstrated the fact that rifled thirty-two pounders even will penetrate our iron sides, while one hundred and twenty pounders merely laugh at the obstruction

div3.p:
" The land batteries of the forts were magnificently served.
If our other shore fortifications would imitate their example, we shall have a different account to give hereafter of encounters between land batteries and vessels.

div3.head: Alexandria.
div3.p:
A gentleman of high character and intelligence has given us a shocking picture of the outrages perpetrated upon helpless women in Alexandria.
It makes the blood run cold to think that such things can be in this 19th century, and in a land pretending to be civilized; things which cannot be transferred to paper, but which, sooner or later, must bring down Divine vengeance on their perpetrators.
We do not believe that Gen. McClellan is aware of these crimes; but, if we could get his hearing we would appeal to him as an honorable foeman to investigate them himself, and, for the sake of humanity and religion, put an end to such inconceivable horrors.

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery to be enlisted for the war. We are happy now to announce that we have procured the guns, which will be ready for us, together with all equipments as soon as our company is mustered into service.
To those who would like to go along with us and share with us the fortunes of this war, we already appear to come forward now and join us at office.
Besides the county of $50, uniforms board and will be furnished free.
Application may be made at our interesting office on Main between 7th and 8th streets, or at the store of Johnston, & Bransford.
div3.closer:
Marmaduk. Johnson,
John W. Branstord,
fe 26--ts A. B. Guigon.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--Having received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Company of Infantry, those who may desire to join it will please report theirselves at my office, on the Law Building, between the hours of 11 and 12 A. M. Meetings will be held also at the same place on each Saturday and Wednesday night, till the company shall have been fully organized.
A bounty of $50, together with subsistence and clothing will be furnished each recruit when he enrolls his name.
div3.closer: fe 28--ts Wm. W. Parker, M. D.

div3.head:
Headquarters, Evansport, Va.,
February 20 1862
div3.p:
Special order No. 33.
All furloughs granted to members of Col. Richardson's regiment (47th Virginia) are hereby revoked, and they are required to join their respective companies immediately.
Those detailed on recruiting service are exempt from the above order.
div3.closer:
By order of Gen. French:
F. H. Reynolds,
fe 24--12t Assistant Adj't General.

div3.head:
Light Artillery!!
battery secured!!!
bounty Fifty Dollars!
div3.p: The undersigned having secured a splendid battery of field pieces, have authority to raise a Company of Light Artillery, to be mustered into the service of the Provisional Army of Virginia, for the war. Each man will be entitled to a bounty of $50 upon being mustered in. As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at once at the rendezvous, northwest corner of Cary and 1th streets, where one or more of the undersigned can always be seen.
Those having substitutes will send them in at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly
div3.closer:
Statleton Crutchfield,
William E Tanner.
Charles E. Wortham.
fe 18--ts

div3.p:
--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery and call upon our follow-of-citizens to come forward and aid getting it up.

We want, if possible, to make a company sufficient to may a battery of guns and think enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus have themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray of the Grenshaw Woolen Company Goods, with, furnished free and the bounty of $50 paid to each man when the company as mustered in.
Rendezvous at the warehouse on the bank, next door to Grenshaw & Co. a where one of the signed may a ways be and maintained free of all expense
The expenses recruits from the country to the city will be paid
div3.closer:
William G. Crenshaw,
James Ellett,
Charles L. Horson,
fe A Drew R. Johnston.

div3.p: The is authorized by the secretary of War, to raise a Regiment of Infantry to for the war. All persons desirous of with him in this a are requested to call at the office of Col. P J. Arcker Commission its at the the corner of Cary and 19th
div3.closer:
Thos. O. Pryton,
fe 3t — 4w Virginia forces.

div3.head:
Artillery
service.
div3.p: The undersigned are authorized to form a
Volunteer.
Artillery Company,
To serve during the war, and have enough men Enrolled to Ensure the Organization, but wish to increase the number to one hundred and twenty-five.
The uniform of the company, for officers and men will be that prescribed by the army regulations of the Confederate States.

While organized under authority from the Secretary of War, the company will form part of the Virginia quota, and in the draft hereafter to be made each town and county will have credit for each member of this company from such town of county.
Persons volunteering herein will be dentition to the bounty as provided by the Acts of the Confederate Congress.
Apply, immediately, in person or by letter, to
div3.closer:
N. A. Sturdivant,
T. M. Hewitt,
Wm. H. Weisiger,
mh 4--6t * Chas. R. Darracott.

div3.p:
--Having reorganized and re-enlisted for two years, is desirous of receiving forty additional recruits, to raise the company to the number or one hundred and fifty.
The battery is composed of four brass six-pounders and two rifle guns, and is among the finest in the Confederate army.
The Fayette Artillery is one of the best equipped companies in the service.
A liberal bounty will be given to each recruit.
Only men of respectability, courage, and patriotism, are, however, required.
For further particulars apply to Peyton Johnston, 115 Main street, Richmond, or to the undersigned, at Yorktown.
div3.closer:
M. C. Macon,
1--6t Capt. R. F. A.

div3.head:
Boys!
boys!! boys!!!
div3.p:
I am to form a Light Artillery company of recruit to 125 members.
I desire, it possible, be composed of boys and young men between the ages of 6 and 21.
The guns will light, not exceding 175 pounds each, of the guns to be used can be seen on hear on the Capitol Square. temperate habits will be permitted
Fifty Dollars bounty will be paid at the time there company is mustered in. On Monday, the the Adjutancy several of the State with hose who have not volunteered After the day you cannot volunteer.
div3.closer: mh 4--3t * Thos T or Pear

div3.head: Attention, Volunteers Fifty Dollars!--Wanted, twenty-five Recruits,
div3.p:
to fill up a No. 1 Infantry Company, to go in Col. Godwin's regiment and be stationed at Portsmouth.
Each man will receive fifty dollars bounty and the company will its own officers.
Apply to

Geo. W. in rear of Dispatch office.
mh 4--3t *

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All arms, public or private, turned in under order of Brigadier-General winder to the C. S Ordnance Department, will be delivered at the Artillery Workshops, of 7th street, beyond the Canal bridge.
div3.closer:
Briscoe G, Baldwin,
1st Lieut artillery.
Richmond Arsenal, March 31, 1862.
mh 4--3t *

div3.head: Recruits Wanted--$50 bounty.
div3.p:
--And Uniforms furnished.--The undersigned, having been duty, authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company of Heavy Artillery, to man the batteries at Yorktown, want a few more men to complete the Company.
For further particulars, apply to Sergeant James McDONALD, 12th street, opposite the Enquirer office.
div3.closer:
W. N. Coffin,
Capt. of Artillery.
S. S. Nicholas,
fe 28--6t * W. P. Woodruff.
Those persons who are desirous of enlisting in my company, will also find a Rendezvous on Franklin st., opposite Messrs. Dickinson, Hill & Co., where an officer may be found to enroll them.

div3.head: Attention, young men of Richmond!
div3.p: Having been detailed to recruit for the First Regiment Virginia Volunteers, (now stationed at ,) a bounty of Fifty Dollars, uniform and subsistence, will be given to all able-bodied young men who may enlist in this the oldest volunteer regiment in the Confederate States.
For further particulars apply at the recruiting station, No. 3, 10th street, between Main and Cary streets.
div3.closer:
W. W. Harrison,
Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer.
P S--Two new companies will be received, its there are at present but eight in the regiment. [mh 3--s] W. W. H.

div3.head:
Recruits--
Richmond Sharp shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Wingfield.
div3.closer:
E. E. De Priest,
mh 3--1m * Lieut and Recruiting Officer.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--The undersigned expects to fill up his company in a few days, with the best material, and those disposed to unite with him had better do so at once.
To be a volunteer is a noble, proud position.
To be a drafted, forced, coerced, militiaman, is almost disgraceful, when it is remembered that we are engaged in the defence of our homes and all we hold most dear in life.
Meetings will be held at my office (Law Building) next Wednesday and Saturday nights, at 8 o'clock.
div3.closer: mh 3--1w W. W. Parker, M. D.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Recruits and Substitutes will be examined by me only, at Royster Hospital, 25th street, between Main and Franklin, from 10 ½ A. M. to 12 ½ P. M.
div3.closer:
O. A. Crenshaw,
mh 3--3t Surgeon G. A. C. S.

div3.head: Public arms.
div3.p: --in pursuance of an act of the General Assembly of Virginia, passed February 12, 1862, all persons in the city of Richmond, not in actual military service are required forth with to deliver to me or the of my deputies, at my Office, 128 Main street, all the muskets, pistols, sabres, and other arms belonging to the State of Virginia of the Confederate States now in their hands; and, as "no person can acquire the right of property to public arms by purchase, passers on or otherwise," I am instructed by the Governor to disregard all such claims.

If any person having such arms in his possession shall fall to produce and deliver the same within twenty days from the publication of this notice, he will be fined according to law, and "forthwith drafted into the service for the war."
All good citizens are earnestly requested to aid in the collection of the public arms, by giving information which will lead to their recovery.
div3.closer:
By order of the Governor.
H. K. Ellyson,
Sheriff City of Richmond.
March 1, 1862. mh 3--3t*

div3.head: University Volunteers.
div3.p: --The undersigned, formerly Captain and First Lieutenant of this company, propose raising another company for the war.
Old members of the company, and others desiring to unite with us, are requested to come forward immediately and aid us in filling up the company.
Fifty Dollars bounty and clothing furnished.
div3.closer:
Jas. P. Crane,
Richmond.
Jas. Dinwiddie,
Greenwood Depot, Albemarle co., Va.
fe 28--1w *

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --As my term of service will expire on the 21st of April, I wish to raise a Volunteer Company, on or before that time, to be mustered into service for the war, or two years. Those who wish to join, can do so by calling on Capt. D. W. Saunders, at the old stand of George Timberlake & Son, on Brook Avenue.
div3.closer:
David B Jones,
fe 22--18t * Company "F," of Richmond.

div3.head:
Attention, citizen soldiers!
Fifty or sixty
able-bodied men, Wanted.
div3.p:
The undersigned having had considerable military experience, and recently attached to the Wise Legion as Captain of Artillery-desires to organize another similar company for immediate service in the Confederate States service.
Each man will be paid Fifty Dollars bounty money when enlisted, and have his uniform furnished.
Now is the time to rally for the defence of our country against the base Yankee invaders.
Headquarters on 10th, between main and Cary streets.
div3.closer:
James Kirby.
fe 27--2w *

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
--The subscribers have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be attached to Major F J. Battalion, to which guns of the most approved kind have been already promised.
As no move flying artillery companies will be received, persons wishing to join this arm of the service will do well to enroll their names at once.
Recent events clearly indicate that Virginia will need the strong arms and brave hearts of all her sons in the impending struggle.
The draft will, within a few days, compel those to take the field who fair to respond to their country's call in this, her hour of peril.
Fifty dollars bounty paid immediately on being mustered in.
Apply at Beyley & White's office, opposite the Law Building.
div3.closer:
Alexander Q Holladay,
Lieut 50th Reg. Va. Vols.
S. Taylor Martin,
1st company Row
Wm F G Garnett, Ja.,
Fayette Artillery.
Richard M. Bolling,
Goochland Troop.

div3.head: Committed to Jail.
div3.p:
--Committed to the jail of Chesterfield county, on the 4th of February, 1862, a Negro calling himself Frederick.
He is five feet five inches high; yellow complexion; about 22 or 23 years of age. He seems to be insane.
The owner is required to come forward, pay charges, and take him away.
mh 4--3t * Wm. A. Graves, Jailor.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to me of my servant girl, Melissa Ann, who absconded on Monday, 24th inst. She is about 17 years of age, 4 ½ feet high, and is of a ginger-bread color.
when she left she had on a red-striped calico dress and checked apron.
W. H. Hardgrove.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Friday nigh last, two negro men, Isaiah and Charles Isaiah is about 28 years of age, black, about 5 feet 8 inches tall, quick spoken and quite intelligent.
Charles is about 45 years old, dark brown complexion 8 or 9 inches high, and not very intelligent.
They were both originally from North Carolina and may be endeavoring to make their way back to that State.
I will give a reward of $25 for the arrest and return of either, or $50 for both.
Robert H. Style.
mh 8--6t* Richmond city.

div3.head: Runaway.--$20 reward
div3.p:
will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to me, corner of 5th and Cary sts., of my man Henry, sometimes calls himself John Henry Evans, who absconded about the 2d inst. He is about 21 years old; black; no scars or marks recollected, very spare made; about 5 feet 6 or 10 inches high.
a blacksmith by trade; a very good barber and dining-room servant; has a wife, I am told, at M. Chas. Friend's, in Chesterfield, where he may are gone, or he may be still in the city.
fe 28--6t* J. H. Word.

div3.head: Ranaway.--$200 reward
div3.p:
--From the residence of the subscriber, on the 30th Nov., Negro Boy Isaac, about 30 years old, 5 ½ feet high, ginger-bread complexion, of pleasant and polite manners, hair short and happy, and a left-handed.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said boy in the jail at Orange C. H.

This negro ran off in consequence of having committed a most brutal and unprovoked murder upon the person of my overseer, and it behooves the community at large to be on the look-out for this criminal.
He may be in the vicinity of Fredericksburg, where he has acquaintances.
Louisa C. Taliaferro,
de 12--d3t&eodts

div3.head: Ranaway.--$100 reward
div3.p:
if found without, $50 if found within this State.
Runaway in November last, Jim, a man about 24 years old. He is about 5 feet 10 or 11 inches high, very thin and delicate looking; has been brought up as a dining-room servant; has sprightly manners; is of a ginger-bread color; has one ankle sprained and limps slightly; has one of his thumbs a good deal enlarged from a whitlow, and has rather red eyes.
The above reward will be paid if he be delivered to Mr. E. D. Eacho, or lodged in a Richmond jail.
fe 27--12t S. P. Flournor.

div3.head: $50 reward for my Servants, John and black well.
div3.p:
John is about twenty-three years old and a carpenter by trade; black and not stout.
He left my residence at the corner of Clay and 10th streets, Sunday morning, the 28d inst at. I have no doubt he is in the employment of some of the companies as a free man, in or near the city, or he may have left it. Blackwell left my farm, in the county of Chesterfield, ten miles above Richmond.
He is 15 years old; a bright mulatto; he has large, dull eyes, thick underlips, spare made knees, and ankles inclined inward.
He left on the 13th instant; he is a house-servant.
I will give twenty-five for one, or fifty for the two delivered to me in Richmond at my residence, corner Clay and 10th streets, or in any all, so that I can get them.
fe 28--6t* G. A. W. Taylor,

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p: --The above reward will be paid, for the apprehension and delivery to me of my servant girl, Melissa Ann, who absconded on Monday, 24th inst. She is about 17 years of age, 4 ½ feet high, and is of a ginger bread color When she left she had on a red striped calico dress and checked apron.
fe 25--6t* W. H. Hardgrove

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p: --A negro boy by the name of Floyd, had been staying with his young master at Evansport, and was taken sick and started home with a man by the name of Dr. H. E. Herst, and the train left him at Burksville, Va. The said boy is about 35 years of age dark complexion, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high.--His general weight is about 150 pounds. Any person taking up the said boy, will have him confined in some safe jail, and I will pay all for his delivery to me.
J. W. Alsobrocks,
fe 17--1m * Mill Town, Alabama.

div3.head: Ranaway.--$25 reward
div3.p:
--A negro man named Gilbert, aged between 40 and 50 years. His color is black; whiskers grey, under the chin.
He is about six feet high; black hair.
His clothing is a black coat and plaid summer pants.
I bought him at Dickinson & Hill's auction last Tuesday.
He was brought here by a gentleman named Thos. G. Neal, of North Carolina.
He left my premises Saturday afternoon, between 2 and 7 o'clock. The above reward will be paid by
H. A. Myers, 66 Main streets
fe 3--1m* Or lodged in some convenient Jail.

div3.head: Runaway in Jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the Jail of the county of Hanover, on the 2d day of September last, as a runaway, a Negro Boy, calling himself Levi Bruington, who claims to be free.
The said Negro is of a dark complexion, and is about 5 feet 9 inches high, and is about 18 years of age, has a scar on right wrist and leg. The said Negro had on when committed a pair of brown Jeans pants and shirt, and a military cap, and is supposed to have escaped from some military company.
The owner of said Negro is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away, else he will be dealt with as the law directs.
C. S. Chisholme.
Acting Jailor of Hanover county Va.
ja 17--2aw6w

div3.head: Runaway in Jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the Jail of the county of Hanover, on the 26th day of June last, as a runaway, a Negro Woman, calling herself Milly, and says she is the property of Peter Pulliam, of the city of Richmond, Va. The said Negro is of a dark complexion, and is about four feet ten inches high, and about 60 years of age, and has on the right shoulder — a scar on same shoulder.
The said Negro had on when committed brown Calico dress.
The owner of the said Negro is requested to come forward, prove property pay charges, and take her away, else she will be dealt with as the law directs.
C. S. Chisholme,
Acting Jailor of Hanover county, Va.
ja 17--2aw6w

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 54, page 4.

div3.head:
The Yankee Brockaders off Charleston.
[correspondence of the N. Y. Times.]

dateline.name: U. S. Steamer Florida, opp Charleston, S. C.,

div3.p:
On the 18th inst. we captured a prize — the ship Emily St. Plerre, of Charleston, S. C, 101 days from Calcutta, loaded with 2,176 bales of gunny-bags.
We think she has saltpetre under the gunny-bags.
We took her crew off, except her captain, steward and cook, and sent her to Philadelphia for adjudication.
There were five vessels in sight at her capture, which will participate in the prize money.
The Florida, flag-ship, James Adger Flambeau, Sumter, and ship Onward.
The vessel is worth about $35,000, and the cargo about $45 or $50 a bale.
It cost three guineas per bale at Calcutta.
She belongs to Charleston, has "Charleston, S. C.," and the arms of Charleston and Augusta, Ga., painted on the glass of her cabin doors, but has an English manifest, which, of course, is only a blind.
We caught her running into Charleston.
This success has aroused us afresh, and we are on the alert constantly.

During the day time everything is quiet and goes on an usual, but as soon as twilight begins to deepen our watchfulness beings.
Our vessel is ready to slip anchor and steam away at an instants warning.
Not a light is to be seen on deck or in the gangways.
At the masthead, yardarms, catheads, gangways, and on the paddle-boxes, are stationed sentries, relieved every two hours, peering into the gloom, on the lookout for lights or dark objects.
Captain Goldsborough peace the deck, cigar in mouth, long after midnight.

Guns are careloose forward, and the quarter gunners and primers stand ready to point and fire at any suspicious object which the darkness may reveal.
Every night we are called to quarters, whether anything is in sight or not.

On the night of the 22d ult., all was still on deck, as I have described, when suddenly, about half an hour after I had turned in, I heard the call to quarters, the anchor slipped, the chain splash as it fell into the water, and the bell strike four; "go ahead fast."

A light had been seen some distance ahead, but had disappeared at the moment we slipped anchor.
We crowded on steam and shaped our course in the direction indicated by the lookout.
In a few minutes the light was again reported from the mashead, and was soon soon distinctly from the paddle-boxes.
I looked for it in vain for a long time and strained ray eyes in the dark until I saw half-a-dozen lights; but we soon came near enough for us to see the vessel itself, and we went after her with all the speed we could command — some seven or eight knots.
As we approached the object, though still three or four miles off, all hands were much excited, as we took her to be the Isabel trying to run in with a cargo of ammunition.
At length we got closer, and as we gained upon her our pivot gun was made to bear on the lights and fired, immediately followed by our forward battery.
As the smoke cleared away the lights became dimmer.
Shot after shot were fired, still keeping up the chase.
Blue lights shone from the chase.
"Never mind that, keep on firing, if she is all right she ought to beave to; fire on until we see that we are gaining on her".
The order was obeyed, and soon we found ourselves gaining, and the bright lights showed us that the strange steamer was lying broadside on, have to.
Then we showed a light, and our captain asked, "What steamer is that?"

p.q: "The United States steamer Oriental, with troops for Port Royal."
"What are you doing at Charleston, then?"

div3.p: "We didn't know we were so close in shore," was the reply.

The captain of the Oriental then came aboard, and after he left we heard that they were very much frigutened, for our shot came all afound them, and the last shot we fired went directly over their quarter-deck, obliging every one in that vicinity to dodge it to save their heads.
They took us for the Nashville, and that was the reason they did not stop at first.

Yesterday the Florida and James Adger went in just beyond the range of Fort Sumter, at least two miles nearer than we had been before.
The casemates of the fort could be counted with the naked eye, and the colors of the flags on Castle Pinckney and Fort Moultrie were castly disticguished without a glass.
We saw two or three steamers and several salling vessels in there.

This morning just after daybreak, we discovered a canoe close alongside.
We took from it five contrabands, among whom was a woman.
They left Charleston at midnight, and passed Fort Sumter without being discovered.
They were almost frozen.
We put them in the engine-room, and when thoroughly thawed out they gave a great deal of information of such importance, that the captain sent them to Port Royal at once, and also sent with them the prisoners taken from the Emily St. Pierre, who had been on board since her capture.
One of the negroes is a blacksmith and the woman is his wife.
He was at Port Royal when we attacked that place, and has been engaged in the rebel Government machine shops.
He was inside of FortSumter yesterday.
He says they have eighty guns there, of which the largest calibre are eight-inch. So our eleven-inch guns are better than any they have.
He also says that they are building a ram at Charleston, and have been working on it night and day for some time, and expect to finish it in thirty days; that there are eight vessels there loaded with cotton, waiting to run out, and that when we and he Adger ran in yesterday, all thought "the Yankees were come, sure;" that crowds and crowds of ladies, as well as men, came down to the docks of the city to examine us through their glasses, and the greatest excitement prevalled throughout the city.
He had planned to run away some time since, and a week ago was all ready, and had an armfull of papers, but the night was too clear.
They came off so suddenly last night that they could bring no papers.
Some more are coming on Friday night.

div3.head: Second Company Johnson's Light Artillery.
div3.p:
More recruits are wanted for this company forthwith.
The conscription will soon be passed, mustering into the service every man in the Confederacy between the ages of 18 and 35, leaving no option with the conscript as to where he shall go, or to what arm of the service he shall belong.

All those who prefer to select the Light Artillery as their service should take at once the last opportunity they will probably have to volunteer.
We desire, at the earliest possible moment, to complete our organization and take the field, where all who are fit for service should be, and where they must be soon, either voluntarily or by compulsion.

Those who have been in service know that the Light Artillery is the most agreeable as well as the most effective arm of the service.
Come at once, then, while the chance is given you to enlist where you please, and relieve yourselves from the opprobrium of compulsory service.
Recruiting Office, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon,
James H. Hackett,
ap 15--ts John H. Leftwich.

div3.head:
Otey battery.
Attention, Volunteers!
div3.p: I am authorized to receive a few good men for this battery, now in Pulaski county, Va., under Col. Jenifer.
This company is composed of our best citizens, including many old Howitzers and Richmond Grays, and persons wishing to join must give reference when not known.
I can be found at the office of the Life Insurance Company, opposite the American Hotel, from 10 to 2 daily, where letters intended for the company may be sent.
div3.closer:
David N. Walker,
1st Lieut. Otey Battery.
Wanted — A good Bugler. Extra pay will be given. ap 15--6t.

div3.head: Hdq'rs Dep't of Henrico,Richmond, Va., April 9th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 13.

I Paragraphs 1 and 2, General Orders No. 12 Headquarters Department of Henrico, issued March 21st, 1862 are not confined in their operationto venders of produce in the markets, but apply to Grocers, Commission Merchants, and every character of dealer in provisions within the city and the surrounding ten miles of country under martial law. All sales of provisions must conform to the Tariff of Prices prescribed by paragraph II.
of General Orders, No. 12; and where not adhered to, both buyer and seller will suffer such punishment as may be imposed by a court martial, and the produce thus sold will be forfeited to the informer, who, if interested in the sale, is exempted from punishment.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder.
L. R. Page,
ap 10--2w Ass't Adj't General.

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry.
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or Regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time, and I now prepose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry.

Persons desiring to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place, or what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call at the office of the Battalion, Main street, Richmond, Va., opposite the office of the Southern Express Company.
div3.closer:
H. Clay Pate,
Capt. Comd'g Cavalry Co.,
ap 10--10t P. A. C. S.

div3.head: Head'rs Dep't of Henrico,Richmond, Va. March 28th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 54.

VI.
Recruits, with or without officers in charge, convalescents and other soldiers, now or hereafter detained in this city, for any cause whatever, will immediately proceed to Camp Winder, near the Reservoir, and report to Colonel John C. Porter, commanding at that post.
div3.closer:
By order of Brigadier General John H. Winder. L. R. Page
mh 31--d4w Assistant Adjutant General.

div3.head: $50 bounty.
div3.p:
--Crescent Zouaves Battalion.
Wanted--Recruits to fill up the battalion of Crescent Zouaves, under the command of Major W. Hyllested.
A bounty of fifty dollars will be paid each recruit upon enlistment.
A near uniform of gray cloth, Zouave style, will be furnished.

This corps will be one of the best organized and equipped in the service, and its commander having had many years' military experience, both in this and foreign countries, will make it a battalion worthy of the admiration of his commanding General, and one that young men will, be proud to serve in, Those wishing to enlist will apply to
div3.closer:
Capt. Wm. T. Fry,
Recruiting Officer,
No. 5 Exchange Block,
ap 1--2w Under Exchange Hotel.

div3.head: Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico, Richmond, Va. March 11, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 6.

II.
Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.
Suporin tendents of railroads are requested to report daily to the Provost Marshal the number of passengers passing over their roads out of the city of Richmond.
div3.closer:
By order of
Brig. Gen'l Jno. H. Winder, Com. &c.
mh 13--ts L. R. Page, A. A. Gen'l.

div3.head: Wise Zouaves.
div3.p:
The undersigned is enlisting a company of Infantry for the 20th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, to be called the Wise Zouaves, in compliment of the memory of the late Captain Wise.
This company will be instructed by Mr. C. F. Pardigon in the Zouave drill of the French Infantry, and taught by him the bayonet exercise.
Being familiar in all its detail, and having aided Captain Car, in the translation of the French works on Bayonet Exercise, his ability to instruct in that drill cannot be questioned.

Militiamen desiring to enter this service will apply to the undersigned, on 12th street, one door above Main.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid the men when mustered into the Confederate service.
div3.closer: ap 3--1m C. F. Pardigon.

div3.head: Maryland Battalion.
div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Pearl street, or by mail to
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
mh 18--ts Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Headquarters Ordnance Departm't, Richmond, Va. March 28th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting State arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock,
mh 29--tf Col. of Ordnance of Virginia.

div3.head: Attention Patriots.
div3.p:
A few more Recruits wanted for Courtney's Artillery, now stationed at Rappahannock river.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid.
Apply at the Franklin House, on 6th between Broad and Marshall streets, to
div3.closer:
Lieut. R. H. Vaughn,
ap 7--10t Or C. M. Christian.

div3.head: Heavy Artillery.
div3.p: $50 Bounty, and Uniforms furnished.

The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.
div3.closer:
Thomas G. Jackson,
mh 17--1m Thomas Lawson.

div3.p: I have been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of heavy Artillery for three years, or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wants only a few companies requisite to its completion.
I should be glad to confer with cantains who have companies, and also with these who desire to raise companies.

p.q: "Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered."

div3.p: Twelve months men can re-enlist singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty; and will also be transferred during the twenty days previous to the expiration of their present term.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies from any pertion of the Confederacy.

Office--Tenth street, three doors from Main.
Clay Post-Office, Box 877.
div3.closer: ap 2--1m Robt. F. Morriss.

div3.head:
Adj't and Ins. Gen's office,
Richmond,April 15, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 86.
[Extract.]

VI. Military Commanders are directed, and officers of the Nitre Bureau are authorized, to seize nitre in the hands of private individuals, who either decline to sell it, or ask more than fifty cents per pound for it. Certificates of impressment will be given by the officer making the seizure, which will entitle the party to the money, when presented to any officer of the Nitre Bureau, or the money may be paid at the time of seizure.
All Quartermasters are directed to give precedence in transportation to nitre over all other Government stores.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
John Withers,
ap 16--1w As't Adj't General.

div3.p:
The First Howitzer Company, having reorganized, will now receive proposals for membership.
Address C. M. Pleasants, at Vau-Lew's hardware store, Main street.
div3.closer:
E. G. McCARTHY, Capt.
Robt. M. Anderson,
Robt. Armistead.
ap 16--6t John Nimmo.

div3.head: Headq'rs Recruiting station 4th Alabama Reg't Volunters, 109 Main street.
div3.p: the following named men have deserted from this station, and the Government reward will be paid for their apprehension:
div3.closer:
M. B. Travis.
2d Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer
ap 1--12t 4th Alabains Volunteers.

div3.head: Attention, Thamsters.
div3.p:
--I wish to enlist ten good Drivers for my Battery.
To experienced men, I will give $50 each in addition to the Government bounty of $50.
Volunteers now in service, but whose term of enlistment will expire during this month, will be received upon application to the undersigned by letter, at Camp Lee, near Richmond.
div3.closer:
Greenlee Davidson,
ap 2--ts Capt. Letcher Artillery.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adj't and Insp. General's office,Richmond, April 8th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 21.
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
Proclamation
"By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habcas corpus:

"I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the Department of East Tennessee under the command of Major-General E. K. Smith; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of willz, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decreas and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to across county levics and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus in the Department aforesaid.
"In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal this 8th day of April, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two
[Signed] Jefferson Davis."

II. Major General M. K. Smith, commanding Department of East Tennessee, is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation.--He will forthwith establish an efficiant military police, and will enforce the following orders: All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distillaries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All person infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a court-martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper,
ap 8--6t Adj't and Inspector General.

div3.head:
Recruitig office,
Richmond April 14, 1862.
div3.p: 50 Reliable Recruits Wanted for an an old company in the 56th regiment Virginia volunteers, Floyd's brigade, now stationed in the Southwest, (at Abingdon, Va.)
Persons wishing to join volunteer companies now have a good chance, with inducements in this company which are rarely to be met with in organized companies.
The usual bounty of Fifty Dollars will be paid each recruit at the time of enlistment.
Call at my office without delay, two doors above 9th and south side of Broad st., up stairs.
div3.closer:
Lieut. Jas. H. Mason,
ap 14--12t REcruiting Officer.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p:
--From my company, at Camp Winder, on Saturday, April 5th, Christopher Brune.
Said Brune is about 30 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches high, auburn hair, brown eyes, and by profession a ship carpenter.
He wore, when he left camp, dark blue coat and pants, grey fatigue cap, with yellow band.
div3.closer:
John Herbig,
Captain Infirmay Company.
All members of my company who are now at large in this city will promptly report at my rendezvous in five days from date, or be considered as deserters.
ap 12--1w John Herbig.

div3.head: Headquarters, pates' Battalion.
div3.p: We, the undersigned, are authorized by Capt. Henry C. Pate, to recruit A Company of Cavalry, consisting of 60 men, to be mustered into the service of the C. S. A. for 3 years or during the war. Members joining this company are entitled to the bounty of $50, and $12 per month pay.

Horses, equipments, and subsistence, furnished each recruit.
Those who furnish their own horses, will be entitled to $25 per month.
Office on Main and near the corner of 9th street, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer:
McNARY Hobson,
ap 7--10t C. F. Harwood.
Norfolk Day Book, Petersburg Express and Richmond Examiner will please copy and send bill to the subscribers.

div3.head: Infantry Company.
div3.p: The undersigned being authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a company of Light Infantry for the war, and having united with Mr. Gharles H. Exall. and Mr. Wm. J. Eggleston and G. W. Jonhs in the enterprise, has opened a Recruiting Office on the West side of 10th street, between Main and Bank. Men enlisting in this company will receive the usual bounty, &c.

This company will form a part of the battalion of infantry being raised by R. G. Scott, Jr., Esq., who may be found at the same office.
[ap 7--1m]

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon,
mh 28--ts Captain Light Artillery.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p:
--Capt. Wm. W. Parker's Company of Light Artillery having been mustered into service, and secured a battery of six guns, are now in the camp of instruction, and will receive a few more Recruits.
if they are of the right sort.
Apply at his office in the Law Building.
at once.
mh 19--ts

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia — a Proclamation.
div3.p: --Whereas,a vacancy has occurred in the House of Delegates of Virginia by the resignation of Richard Irby, the member elected from the District composed of the counties of Amelia and Notoway; Therefore,I, John Letcher, Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, by virtue of authority vested in the Executive by law, do hereby require the Sheriffs of the said counties of Amelia and Nottoway to hold an election, at the several places of voting prescribed by law in said counties, on the 24th day of the present month, (April,) for a Delegate to fill the vacancy aforesaid.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 7th day of April, 1862, and in the year of the Commonwealth the eighty-sixth.
div3.closer:
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
George W. Munford,
Secretary of the Commonwealth.
Petersburg papers please copy. ap 10td

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--A Negro Boy, named David; about 20 years old; of medium height; black skin.
No scare recollected.
He is slow in his movements.
It is supposed he is lurking about the city.
Has been at the Central Hotel, and has probably hired himself at some of the camps.--Ten dollars reward will be paid for his return, if caught within the city, or county of Henrico; $25 if caught beyond.
Ro. D. Ward, or
ap 16--1 A. D. Williams.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on the 12th April, our negro man Robert.
He is about 22 years old, and about 5 feet 10 inches high; well built; quite dark, and full featured.
Had on when he left light woolen clothes and a wide-brim black felt hat; was bought recently from H. M. Marshall, Fauquier county, Va. $50 reward will be given for his delivery to us; $25 for his delivery to any of the jails.
ap 15--3t Talbott & Bro.

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p: --Ranaway from the subscriber on the morning of the 14th instant, from my farm, near the Junction in Hanover county, my negro man Dick, of a dark gingerbread complexion, about five feet six inches in height, and very quick in speech when spoken to. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me on my farm, or in the Hanover county jail, or any jail in the city of Richmond.
Thomas Doswell.
Junction, Hanover county, Va.

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, a negro man named John.
Said follow is about 25 years of age, 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, has a down look when spoken, to and of dark color; has his hair plaited and wears his beard long, and is a blacksmith by trade, and may have hired himself to some smith in the city as a free man. I will give the above reward if said fellow be taken fifty miles South of Richmond, or twenty dollars if apprehended anywhere else and delivered to Messrs. Clopton & Lyne.
ap 14--5t John Palmer.

div3.head: $25 reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thickest, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
S. S. Cottrell.
ap 2--ts No. 129 Main street.
